Expectation1: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation1: Midway through the week, their individual sales numbers are already on pace to surpass the quota.
Expectation2: Conduct daily prayers and religious services for the community
Situation2: Should attend the most significant religious holiday of the year, which draws the largest attendance.
Story: I stared at my computer screen, the sales dashboard glowing with numbers that told me I was on track to break my personal record. My manager’s words echoed in my mind: “Push harder, close every call, don’t let up.” The thrill of success buzzed in my chest, but as I glanced at the clock, a cold wave of guilt washed over me. Tonight was the most significant religious holiday of the year, and as the community’s priest, I was expected to lead the prayers and guide everyone through the sacred rituals. My phone rang again—another potential customer, another chance to climb higher in the rankings. But I knew the congregation would be gathering soon, waiting for me to open the doors, to offer comfort and hope. My hands trembled as I weighed the demands: the relentless drive for sales, the sacred duty to my faith. I felt torn, pulled in two directions, each role demanding all of me, and I sat frozen, unable to choose which expectation to betray.
